captions.text:
One up. Vsauce, Nintendo just released the
Wii U, it's 6th home console. But they actually

got their start in 1889, making the company
123 years old.

They began by making Hanafuda Cards which
are Japanese playing cards, and then went

on, obviously, to make video games like Donkey
Kong, which was originally supposed to be

a Popeye game, and Mario, which I'm playing
right now. Their first console, the Nintendo

Entertainment System, sold so many games that
if you stacked them on top of one another,

it would be over 6,000 miles high, which is
taller than Mount Everest, and, more than

1,000 miles...one up...further than the distance
between myself and...

Me, Michael, from Vsauce. And, yeah, Kevin
lives very far away from me- 8 times zones

away from me. He lives in Oregon, and I live
in the United Kingdom, but it's nice to know

that all those Nintendo games stacked together
would be more than enough to connect us. But
let's keep these facts going.

If you looked at all those Nintendo games
you would find a surprising amount featuring

Ken Griffey Jr. But, it's actually not surprising
because ever since 1992, Nintendo has owned

a baseball team: the Seattle Mariners. But
that's not the only super-cool thing that

Nintendo owns. They've also trademarked the
phrase "It's on like Donkey Kong."

In 1982 the game and watch developers at Nintendo
invented something legendary- the D-pad. In

a cross shape, with a little, shallow middle-
they patented it. But, according to Pocket

Gamer, in the early 2000's Nokia and Nintendo
were planning a telephone. Apparently the

research and development efforts were quite
successful, but, unfortunately, the idea was
ultimately rejected.

One of my favorite pieces of Nintendo trivia
is, in my opinion, kind of creepy, in a cool

way. Kazumi Totaka has hidden the same simple
little melody in dozens of Nintendo games.

And what you have to do to get the game to
play the song is often quite strange- almost

like the song doesn't want to be discovered,
but, if given time, will show itself. When

you listen to the song it's pretty eerie.
I highly recommend you go watch a quite interesting,

but informative, video series about "Totaka's
Song." It's down in the description.

Before I send you back to Kevin, I'm going
to leave you with something cute: Kirby. A

cute, pink puffball. But the only thing cuter
is Kirby's original name. No, he wasn't always

known as Kirby. Before he came to the United
States, he was going to be called Tinkle PoPo.
And, as always...thanks for watching.

comments.text:
okay okay okay. this video left out a very large portion of Nintendo 
history, and one of the facts wasn't entirely correct. firstly, Nintendo 
did a lot of things before video games. after they realized the limits of a 
humble card company, they went on to do all sorts of things. they made 
things like love testers, toys and even a taxi service. and when they 
started in videogames, it wasn't even with the nes. before the nes, they 
had the colour tv six, which (as the name implies) was a home console with 
six built in games. they even made a colour tv 12. ﻿

comments.text:
How about the fact that Nintendo is responsible for the development of the 
PlayStation?  The PS1 was originally going to be CD add-on for the SNES 
(similar to the Sega CD).  When Nintendo decided to break their agreement 
with Sony, Sony realized they had half of a functioning game console, and 
decided to continue the project and release their very own, competing 
console: the Sony PlayStation.﻿

+Mike Davids i think he might have misunderstood me...

the wii u MACHINE is not powerfull enough, nor does it have enough games i 
want (might check a used model a while from now, current goal is ps4)

BUT while the machine itself is mediocre the controller IS NOT...

the 360 controller is nice, the ps3 controller is clunkily small.. now im 
not into n64 size, although that was more design but since the left half 
was rarely used it didnt matter..

even the vita is tiny..

IMO handheld consoles should be the size of the wii u CONTROLLER...
not some small nanotech you cant use and constantly overreach with your 
fingers and such... 

that AND with a handheld console at that size it leaves more room for sweet 
stuff, such as quallity buttons (vita has in all but the triggers, the 3ds 
remarkably has in all buttons except the analouge stick which it only has 
one off) and hardware sweet sweet hardware.


theres a reason i went for a 17 inch laptop and not a 15 inch.
